comments.body:
A separate bug for the following failure was marked duplicate of this bug.  I am adding this info so hopefully searching the database on the junit failure will show up this bug.  This problem is causing regression test failures in 10.3 also so adding that to the affected list:
This is failing on trunk, sun 1.6:
http://dbtg.thresher.com/derby/test/Daily/jvm1.6/testing/testlog/w2003/530080-suitesAll_diff.txt
1) statementJdbc20(org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.jdbcapi.JDBCHarnessJavaTest)junit.framework.ComparisonFailure: Output at line 3 expected:<... parameter value '-1[,]000' for Statement.s...> but was:<... parameter value '-1[?]000' for Statement.s...>
	at org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.util.CanonTestCase.compareCanon(CanonTestCase.java:100)
	at org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.util.HarnessJavaTest.runTest(HarnessJavaTest.java:90)
	at org.apache.derbyTesting.junit.BaseTestCase.runBare(BaseTestCase.java:88)

	at junit.extensions.TestSetup$1.protect(TestSetup.java:21)

author.name: knutanders
author.emailAddress: knut dot hatlen at oracle dot com

comments.body: You're right, calling junit.framework.Assert.fail() should also work. The only difference is that it will stop the test, whereas with System.out.println() the test continues after the failure. But since the test is not yet a JUnit test, I'm not sure we should add to many of the JUnit constructs. I think assertSQLState() makes sense since it helps us work around a problem with canon based tests. I don't think using fail() gives us anything more than println() in this test, though.
